title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
Meaningful Summaries by Scale Type








Quick check


Which statistics are meaningful at each scale?






Count works best for Nominal / Ordinal
Median & Percentiles work best for Ordinal+.
Mean & Standard Deviation work best for Interval / Ratio.










Textbook vs Real World


These rules are bent often; the real world is messy

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
When SUM is meaningful


The variable is additive

Units can be totaled (minutes, dollars, people, rows)

0 means ‘none’




Examples

Total minutes delayed
Total injuries
Number of severity 3 accidents (sum of 1/0)
Total distance?

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
When SUM is not meaningful


It’s an ID or label

It’s ordinal (e.g., severity 1–4)

It’s already an average/rate



Examples

Sum of accident IDs
Sum of severity codes
Sum of ‘average speed’ (unless weighted)
Sum of temperature?











Fast Test


Can you add two rows together and keep the same meaning + units?

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
Sample size or Row Count

Four counts to keep straight


N — Total records in the dataset

neligible — After filters (date, severity, etc.)

nnon-missing — Non‑missing for the chosen variable

n — Actual usable values for our analysis

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
Central Tendency

We have three common flavors—each answers a different question.

Mean: balancing point; sensitive to outliers.
Median: middle value; robust to skew/outliers.
Mode: most frequent value; useful for categorical data.

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
Standard Deviation


Variance (s2 or σ2): average squared distance from the mean.



Standard deviation (s or σ): typical distance in original units.

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
Percentiles & Quartiles

The Pth percentile is the value with P% of data at or below it.

The 10th percentile (P10) is the value where 10% of the distribution is lower and 90% is higher
The 82nd percentile (P82) is the value where 82% of the distribution is lower and 18% is higher
Quartiles are P25 (Q1), P50 (Q2), P75 (Q3)
The 50th (P50) percentile, the 2nd Quartile (Q2) and the Median are all the same value

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
Mean and SD
Unstandardized measures depend on the units being measured

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
Percentiles
Standardized measures do not depend on units being measured

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text: IQR - Inter-Quartile Range

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text: Boxplots or Box & Whisker Plots

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
Cross Tabs or Contingency Tables
Start with counts; then layer in percentages.


Frequncy Table - *One Categorical Variable
Cross Tab - Two Categorical Variables
Count how many rows n
Add marginal totals



Compute Percentages

row % (conditional on row)
column % (conditional on column)
table % for overall share

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
What can go wrong?


Confusing similar-sounding percentages:



% of incidents that happened in Spring and in the Morning?




% of incidents in the Spring that happened in the Morning?




% of incidents that happened in the Spring?










Percentage Problems


Make sure you are clear on what the numerator and denominator are and communicate clearly.

title: Week 2 — Descriptive Measures
text:
Correlation

Correlation (r): standardized between -1 and +1
Shows strength of linear pattern.
+1 means positive relationship, -1 means netagive relationship
Does not determine the slope of the line
Regression analysis needed for full understanding








Caution


Correlation ≠ Causation. Check for confounders, nonlinearity, and outliers. E.g. perform a full regression analysis.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
What is Statistics?
What is Analytics?

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text: Analytics is the art of finding out what is in your data.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text: If you can (with some effort) find the answer with certainty you are using Analytics.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
Analytics deals with what you know.
Statistics deals with what you do not know.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
Analytics turns curiosity into questions.
Statistics turns data into answers.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
Analytics is the art of finding out what is in your data.
Statistics is the science of making decisions under uncertainty.



Open with intuition: students already do analytics informally.
Emphasize uncertainty as the key dividing line.
Pause after the third fragment and ask for examples.

Principles of Tidy Data

Each variable you measure should be in one column
Each observation of that variable should be in a different row
There should be one table for each type of observational unit
If you have multiple tables you need a key to link them

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
Before we run any statistics…








Guiding Question


What can go wrong before you ever run a statistical test?

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
What is Statistics?
What is Analytics?

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text: Analytics is the art of finding out what is in your data.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text: If you can (with some effort) find the answer with certainty you are using Analytics.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
Analytics deals with what you know.
Statistics deals with what you do not know.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
Analytics turns curiosity into questions.
Statistics turns data into answers.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
Analytics is the art of finding out what is in your data.
Statistics is the science of making decisions under uncertainty.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
Analytics or Statistics

Count the number of airbnb properties within 1 mile of Wrigley Field
Predict how many bookings an airbnb property will have next year
Testing whether changing cancellation policy caused higher satisfaction




Open with intuition: students already do analytics informally.
Emphasize uncertainty as the key dividing line.
Pause after the third fragment and ask for examples.

title: ECO 230 Section 012
text:
Principles of Tidy Data


Each variable you measure should be in one column
Each observation of that variable should be in a different row
There should be one table for each type of observational unit
If you have multiple tables you need a key to link them










Nerd Alert.


Tidy Data principles are a solution to a problem, not rules that must be followed.

Summary and Prime Directive

Before running any statistics, what are the three questions you must answer about a dataset?
 1. What does one row represent?  2. What kind of variables do I have?  3. What question can this data answer?

title: Study Guide — Video 2
text:
Identify each measurement scale (nominal, ordinal, interval, ratio).
Recognize when averages make sense and when they don’t.
Understand discrete vs. continuous variables.
Know how variables are coded behind the scenes.






Nominal = categories without order (e.g., shirt color, ZIP code).
Ordinal = categories with order (e.g., GPA brackets, class rank).
Interval = numeric scale without a meaningful zero (e.g., Fahrenheit).
Ratio = numeric scale with a real zero (e.g., GPA as a continuous number, height, weight).
Discrete = whole units (e.g., number of people).
Continuous = can take fractional values (e.g., weights, GPAs).
Averages are meaningful for ratio data; sometimes meaningful for ordinal; rarely meaningful for nominal.
Computers assign numeric codes to categories, but that doesn’t make them numerical.







Categorical labels without inherent order.



Categories with meaningful ranking, but distances between categories are unknown.



Numeric scale where differences make sense but zero is arbitrary.



True numeric scale with a real zero; ratios are meaningful.








Which scale is GPA when recorded exactly (e.g., 3.27)?


Nominal



Ordinal



Interval



Ratio
Correct answer: D


On which scale does it not make sense to compute an average?


Nominal



Ordinal



Interval



Ratio
Correct answer: A


“Freshman → Sophomore → Junior → Senior” is:


Nominal



Ordinal



Interval



Ratio
Correct answer: B







Give an example of why treating nominal data as numeric can be misleading.

Explain why Fahrenheit is an interval scale.

Describe a variable you use in real life and identify its scale.







“Explain each measurement scale using analogies from sports or gaming.”
“Give me 10 examples of variables and ask me to classify their scale.”
“Convert a ratio variable into an ordinal scale and explain what information is lost.”
“Give me trick questions that test whether I understand when averages make sense.”

title: Study Guide — Video 1
text:
Understand the purpose and sequence of the ETL process.
Distinguish between raw, unstructured, and structured data.
Recognize why transformation is central to analysis.
Identify common data sources and loading destinations.






Extract = Getting the data from its source (database, website, sensor feed, file, etc.).
Transform = Cleaning, formatting, reshaping, and standardizing so it’s consistent.
Load = Bringing the cleaned data into the tool where analysis happens (Excel, R, Tableau, DBs).
Most analysis work happens in the Transform stage.
Data from third‑party sources often requires substantial cleanup.
Structured vs. unstructured sources influence how much transformation is needed.







Moving data from source → computer or tool. This could be downloads, APIs, database connections, or streaming sources.



Ensuring variables are consistent: - date formats
- numerical types
- categorical codes
- missingness
- pivoting between tall/wide
This enables charts, summaries, and models to behave predictably.



Final storage in the analysis environment.
Sometimes data is loaded back to the original DB; sometimes directly into R, Excel, etc.









A)  Extract\


Transform



Load



Archive
Correct answer: B



A)  Reformatting dates\


Downloading a CSV from the Census Bureau



Creating new variables



Writing a SQL summary
Correct answer: B

Moving data into the analysis tool



Generating summaries



Interpreting charts
Correct answer: B

title: Transcript — Video 2 (Measurement Scales)
text:
Transcript — Video 2 (Measurement Scales)
So once you have an idea of what data is in our dataset, how it’s tract, it’s good to take a look at those variables and think, Okay, how is this data is actually stored? Either How was it coded? How is it stored numerically? Is that gonna be useful for us? Is it going to be, is it going to tell us the information that we need? Or do we need to go look at data from a different source?
So textbook definition of how data is measured is as follows. As follows. Here, we talked a little bit about those categorical variables. There’s numeric variables. But this type of data and how it’s stored. It is also important to know what’s the scale that the date is on. So textbook definition, we have nominal ordinal, interval and ratio scale data. And this is getting into, once we have this data, numerically, what we do with it mathematically.
Nominal scale is the lowest level. This is a naming type verbal, so the categories that we have are just there for naming purposes just to keep track of. Okay. This person isn’t, this, isn’t this category or not. It’s usually a categorical type scale.
Ordinal scale is the same sort of thing. We looked at this a little bit with categorical scales where there’s some order inherent to the, to the way the data is tracked.
(… transcript continues …)

title: Transcript — Video 3 (Tidy Data & Structure)
text:
Transcript — Video 3 (Tidy Data & Structure)
So we’ve talked a little bit about how to get the data that we need into our hands onto your computer to do our analysis. Once we have our data ready to go, It’s always good to open up that dataset, take a look at it and get a sense of what is this data actually going to be telling us? How is the houses data stored? Is it in a format that’s gonna be, it’s gonna be useful for analysis. Or do we need to do some additional work in that transform space where we’re getting that data set up and organized just how we want it.
First thing to think about is, how is this, these variables, this data is measuring. How is that data being stored or represented in our spreadsheet or in the database that we’re looking at. It’s usually going to break into two main categories. Categories as a category here. So this would be if our data has discrete things that it’s measuring.
Simple example would be like a true‑false variable. Does this person live on‑campus true or false? It’s going to be a one or a zero. Logical yes or no, sort of a thing.
(… transcript continues …)

title: Transcript — Video 1 (ETL)
text:
Transcript — Video 1 (ETL)
It’s usually one of our first task is figuring out how to get the data where we need it to be in order to use it and do our analysis on it. So generally when we’re getting data, it’s going to follow this type of a process, extract, transform load or ETL process. A lot of the data that we’re gonna be working with, especially for this course, is going to be data that other people have gathered what’s known as secondary data. Later on in the class, we will talk little bit about primary data, how to, how to gather data for a specific purpose. But the vast majority of the time we’re gonna be using data that’s already existing and whether it is from a third party source or internally within our company has sales database or something like that. We usually don’t have a lot of say in how their data is structured, how it’s set up. So we need to figure out how to get that data in the form that it’s in currently. And then get it into a form that we’re gonna be able to do. Our nails the sun.
The first step in that process is to extract the data. And that is to get the data from wherever it is to our computer, to where we’re gonna be working with it at. That data can take on a number of different forms. Sometimes the data is relatively clean. If it is a something like this where we have a structured database where everything is set up just so you know, each point of data is in its own row, each specific variables in its own column. So sometimes it might be pretty much in the form that we need to use it, right where it is.
Other times you might be grabbing it from a website or something like that. If you wanted to do some analysis looking at census data, you will go to the Census Bureau’s website and download data from there. It might just be unstructured data just pouring into, into a database, some sort of a sensor or something that is tracking data, looking at a motion sensor or something like that. Where, you know, every time that that sensor is triggered, it it changes from a truth or false yes or no sort of a thing. Measuring the brightness or measuring the voltage of a certain sensor. Measuring whether or not motion was detected on a video camera. That data might just be constantly pouring in. And then we have to figure out, okay, how we’re gonna deal with this L. We’re going to figure out what the timestamp was. What does this data, what is it telling us?
That first step is to is to extract that data. So get it out of where it is right now. Get it to where we need it to be. Once we have that data downloaded or transferred over to where we’re gonna be using it or connected to, you know, sometimes we don’t actually need the data, we just make a connection to where it’s at. Next step is to transform that data to get it into a format that’s going to be convenient for us to use that we can do analysis on without a constantly having to go in and edit things and change things and recalculate. So that’s the T part of the ETL process transform to get the data from the form that it’s in when we get it, to change it to the form that we’re gonna be using it for our analysis.
So a lot of times we’re editing this data, so it’s gonna be stored in a consistent way. It’s gonna be efficient for us to go and look at it. There’s certain rules that we’re going to follow that’s gonna make our lives much easier when it comes time to analyze that data or build a chart or do some analysis on it. There are some standard ways to keep that where any tool that we’re going to connect to that data width is going to be able to look at it in a similar way.
The example on the top here, that a good before if we download data from the Census Bureau, It’s gonna look something like this. So this data is stored in a way where we have gigabytes of data on. However many million people live in the country. All that data is stored on a server somewhere in a way that’s going to be convenient for the Census Bureau. That’s not necessarily convenient for us. You can see we have a lot of empty space here. If category one, category to category three, you might not know what those things mean.
A lot of times we need to transform that data to get it into something. It’s going to be a little bit more convenient for us to use consistent way to measure what was the time that his data was recorded? Consistent way to measure geographically, what was their zip code? What was the date of what was what were the different categories that it falls into? A lot of times we can store that in a much more efficient way. We do it as part of the transform process.
Last step then is to load it into the program that we’re gonna be using to do our analysis. In this can be anything. Sometimes we go from a database, we transform it and put it right back into that same database. This doesn’t necessarily have to be different programs that we’re using.
(… transcript continues …)

title: Study Guide — Video 3
text:
Identify the unit of analysis in any dataset.
Distinguish cross‑sectional, time‑series, and panel data.
Understand dimensions vs. measures.
Recognize tall vs. wide data structures.
Apply the four principles of tidy data.






Unit of analysis = what each row represents.
Cross‑sectional = different subjects at one time.
Time‑series = measurements over time (subjects may differ).
Panel = same subjects over time.
Tall data = many rows; good for grouping, pivoting, combining.
Wide data = many columns; good for fast lookups.
Dimensions = categories for slicing/filtering (e.g., person, month, location).
Measures = numeric values to summarize (e.g., mean sleep minutes).
Tidy data principles:

Variables in columns

Observations in rows

One table per observational unit

Keys connect tables








The entity described by each row (person, transaction, date, etc.).



Categorical descriptors used for slicing or grouping.



Numerical values used for summaries like average, count, standard deviation.



Two orientations of the same underlying information.








Which dataset structure is ideal for pivoting between categories?


Wide



Tall
Correct answer: B


A dataset tracking the same individuals every month is:


Cross‑sectional



Time‑series



Panel
Correct answer: C


“Month, Location, Person” in a sleep‑tracking dataset are:


Measures



Dimensions
Correct answer: B







Describe a dataset from real life and identify its unit of analysis.

Explain why tall datasets are usually easier to join and aggregate.

Describe when you would prefer a wide dataset.

title: Homework 1: Data Anatomy & Responsible AI Use
text:
NotePurpose



This assignment helps you practice the three essential questions from Week 1:

What does one row represent? (unit of analysis / grain)

What kinds of variables do I have? (types + NOIR measurement scales)

What can this data actually answer? (analytical frame)

You will work with real microdata, evaluate its structure, and reflect on how to use AI responsibly to accelerate—not replace—your thinking.

title: Homework 1: Data Anatomy & Responsible AI Use

title: Homework 1: Data Anatomy & Responsible AI Use
section: 2) Is Your Data Tidy? Why or Why Not?
text:
2) Is Your Data Tidy? Why or Why Not?
Using the Week 1 tidy data principles:

Each variable in its own column

Each observation in its own row

One table per type of observational unit

Keys required if multiple tables link

Write 3–5 sentences answering:

Is your dataset tidy? Why or why not?

If it’s not tidy, identify the issue (e.g., wide layout, mixed grains, repeated headers, embedded units).

title: Homework 1: Data Anatomy & Responsible AI Use
text:

title: Homework 1: Data Anatomy & Responsible AI Use
text:
4) Build a Pivot Table (Dimensions + Measures)
Create an Excel pivot table using:

≥ 1 Dimension (categorical descriptor: ZIP, Gender, Date, Location, Category)

≥ 1 Measure (numeric summary: Count, Average, Total, Min/Max)

If you encounter errors, briefly describe what happened and what you tried.
(Optional: include a screenshot.)

title: Homework 1: Data Anatomy & Responsible AI Use
section: 5) What Is the Unit of Analysis?
text:
5) What Is the Unit of Analysis?
In 3–5 sentences, explain:

What one row represents in your dataset (the grain)

Why this grain matters for answerable questions

What information would appear if the grain were more detailed

Remember your training:

“Rows are never just rows. If you misunderstand the unit of analysis, every result is wrong—even with perfect code.”

title: Homework 1: Data Anatomy & Responsible AI Use
text:

If a type is missing, describe the additional data you would need.

Categorical (Nominal):

Continuous Numeric:

Date/Time:

Geographic/Spatial:

(You may list more than one variable for a given type.)

title: Homework 1: Data Anatomy & Responsible AI Use
text:
7) Responsible Use of AI (Required)
AI can accelerate learning, but it must not interpret results or make analytical decisions for you.
Use AI only for clarification, rewriting, or troubleshooting.
Write 5–7 sentences responding to:
A. How did you use AI on this assignment?
(If not at all, state that and why.)
B. What did AI help with? (Be specific.)
C. What did AI get wrong, miss, or oversimplify?
D. Include one AI prompt you used and note:
- How the response helped
- Where it fell short
Remember our goal with AI:

“Can you use AI responsibly to accelerate—not replace—your thinking?”

title: Homework 1: Data Anatomy & Responsible AI Use
text:
8) Submission
Upload to Canvas:

Your completed Excel workbook (.xlsx)

A document (Word/PDF or Canvas text entry) with your responses, including the AI reflection

Please bring your .xlsx file to class for in‑class demonstrations.

title: Homework 1: Data Anatomy & Responsible AI Use
text:

Choose the right analysis: You identify grain, tidy structure, and variable types to determine valid analyses.

Interpret results in context: Your pivot and explanations tie summaries to what the data can and cannot answer.

Explain limitations, assumptions, and uncertainty: Your AI reflection and grain discussion surface constraints before statistics.

title: ECO 230 Business and Economic Research & Communication
text:
Course description
Building on the foundation in statistics acquired in STAT 145, students will continue to develop and will apply skills in data analysis to aid in business decision making. These skills include data collection, data summarization, data visualization, statistical inference, and communication of data in business contexts. Students will learn and apply best practices for research design and analysis to address authentic business cases. Students will build these skills in collaboration with each other and through engagement with business and community leaders. The course also discusses effective survey design and current privacy and ethical issues in collecting and using data. Prerequisite: ENG 110 or ENG 112; STAT 145; CBA major, CASSH economics major, or healthcare analytics management minor. Offered Fall, Spring.

Prerequisites
Prerequisite: ENG 110 or ENG 112; STAT 145; CBA major, CLS economics major, or Healthcare Analytics Management Minor.

title: ECO 230 Business and Economic Research & Communication
text:
Learning outcomes

Mapped to CBA Undergraduate Curriculum Goals and Objectives

Develop the ability to articulate a business problem or opportunity using qualitative and quantitative evidence and propose an analysis plan to identify potential solutions, including collection of primary data via surveys. (CT-1)
Describe, summarize, and interpret data using descriptive statistics, inferential statistics, and data visualization.
Develop foundational skills related to spreadsheets, interactive data visualization software, and scripting languages used for data analysis and visualization.
Communicate the purpose, methods, and results of analysis to authentic audiences in appropriate written and oral formats. (CS-1, CS-2)
Apply research design and data analysis best practices to complete case-based projects and to critique others’ analyses. (CT-1)
Describe current debates in research ethics and data privacy and the implications for business research. (SR-1)



CBA Undergraduate Curriculum Goals and Objectives referenced above

Communication Goal: Our students will be able to convey information and ideas effectively.

(CS-1) Learning Objective: Students will convey information and ideas in professional business reports

(CS-2) Learning Objective: Students will convey information and ideas in oral presentations.

Decision Making and Critical Thinking Goal: Our students will be able to think critically when evaluating decisions.

(CT-1) Learning Objective: Students will evaluate alternatives and understand the ramifications of those alternatives within a given business context.

Social Responsibility Goal: Students will demonstrate the role of social responsibility in business decisions.

(SR-1) Learning Objective: Students will be able to identify and apply different frameworks of social responsibility to business problems and recognize the short- and long-term effects on stakeholders and society.


Remaining CBA Goals and Objectives along with rubrics for each can be found here:
https://www.uwlax.edu/cba/undergraduate-curriculum-learning-goals-and-objectives2/#tmcommunication-goals

title: ECO 230 Business and Economic Research & Communication
text:
Grading

Calculations
Your overall grade consists of the following assessments, arranged by type and value. Your final grade can be computed by multiplying the scores received by the percentages reported below to arrive at a weighted average. Team assignments are denoted by (T) but please note grades received for team project deliverables will be adjusted by your Peer Evaluation score.




Assignment


#


Total % Final Grade






Homework, Lab Prep & In Class Labs


~10


20%




Quizzes


~5


20%




Final Exam & Practicum


1


20%




Case Projects (T)


2


30%




Participation / Discussion




10%




Total




100%






Calculation of individual grades for team project work
All work for the assignments denoted as Team Projects by (T) above will be scored out of 100 points to assign a Team Grade. Individual grades will be computed by multiplying the Team Grade by the CATME peer evaluation score you receive for that work. The CATME peer evaluation is a psychometrically validated and behaviorally anchored rating scale developed under a National Science Foundation Grant and used by universities throughout the country. Through a secure web-based platform, you will rate your own and your teammate’s performance on each project. This information will be reported in the aggregate to your teammates (they cannot see who gave them what scores) and will produce a Peer Evaluation Score. Most students receive a score of 1, those that exhibit exceptional performance receive scores above 1 with a maximum of 1.05. Underperforming teammates receive scores below 1, and as low as 0.4.






Note



Note: This is not a “zero sum game”. It is possible for team members to get scores above 1 without others getting scores below. The algorithm flags evaluations that appear to manipulate ratings to inflate their own scores. Your score will automatically be reduced by 0.05 if you fail to complete the Peer Evaluation on or before the due date.




Grievance procedure for peer evaluation scores
Poor peer evaluations can lead an individual grade to fall substantially below the Team Grade. For example, a project that received a score of 95/100 would produce an individual grade of 38/100 if you receive a peer evaluation score of 0.4. If you feel the score you received does not accurately reflect your contributions to Team Project work, you have the option to file a grievance. To do so you must follow this procedure:

Within 2 business days of the official notification that grades have been posted, communicate to your instructor via email your intent to file a grievance. Official notifications of grade posting will appear on Canvas notifications.
Within 1 business day of notifying your intent, prepare and email a one page formal letter addressed to your teammates and including the following information:

Your understanding of the work you had agreed to do for the deliverable. Be sure to refer to any documentation that is relevant (Meeting Minutes, emails or group chats, revision histories in documents etc.). Be prepared to provide any documentation you mention in the letter if requested.
A summary of the work you actually did. Refer to documentation as above.
Justification for any discrepancies between (a) and (b). If this documentation includes any confidential health or personal matters you do not wish to disclose to your team, please raise this with me or contact Student Life Office for council. Note: In these cases it is best to reach out to me or Student Life before you are at the point of receiving a bad peer evaluation.
A statement of the peer evaluation score you believe you have earned.

If after reviewing your letter I believe the case has merit, I will send it on to your teammates and schedule an arbitration. If I determine no arbitration is warranted, I will schedule a one-on-one meeting with you to discuss.
If arbitration is warranted, it must be conducted in-person with all team members present. The only exception to this requirement would be a case where the timeline in the procedure would place the earliest possible arbitration date after the final exam date. In those cases, a virtual meeting may be agreed upon or incomplete grades may be assigned until an in-person meeting can be scheduled. I will serve as the arbitrator. You and your teammates will have the opportunity to present your case and reconcile evidence referenced in your letter. At the end of the meeting, all team members (including yourself) will submit the score they believe you have earned to me via secret ballot. I will use this information in making my final determination, but the final determination is mine alone.



Late assignments, missed quizzes

Individual assignments






Warning



Individual assignments are due on the dates indicated on the Canvas Weekly Agendas. Late or missing assignments will not be graded. All assignments in a module must be completed before the Module Quiz. If extenuating circumstances impact your ability to meet deadlines or participate in class activities, you are responsible for alerting me as soon as possible. When conflicts are known ahead of the deadline you must notify me ahead of the deadline. All communication regarding missed or late individual work should be confirmed by email – even if we speak in person or during student hours, you must follow up via email to confirm so that we both have a record of the agreement.




Team assignments
Deadlines for Team Assignments may be extended for the entire class if there are extenuating circumstances or granted to teams if requested with appropriate justification and all team members agree to the request. Presentations cannot be delayed unless there is a major emergency or complication. For other deliverables, extensions must be requested at least 1 business day before the due date. Be prepared to show appropriate documentation of work to date and to provide an explanation for the value you will add to the final product if the extension is granted. Unless a request is made and granted, late assignments will receive a grade of 0.


Missed quizzes
Quizzes may be rescheduled only in the case of serious illness, injury, or significant academic or professional development opportunity. Personal travel or family vacations will not be accommodated unless they are associated with a significant life event (birth, death, marriage, graduation). In all cases, documentation is required. Contact me via email as soon as you know you have a conflict. Local or phone/Skype job interviews are not considered significant professional development opportunities.



Attendance and participation
Although attendance will not be formally recorded for all class meetings, your Team can and should reduce your peer evaluation score if you miss meetings or are absent during in class Work Days. To avoid this consequence, you should:

Communicate clearly with your team any time you will be absent from a Team Meeting or class on a day that includes Case Work Time.

Document that communication (e.g. save emails or post to team message board).

Participate actively in scheduling Team Meetings outside of class.

Lay out policies on scheduling team meetings and missed meetings and follow them.

Respect others’ time and reserve absences for only when absolutely unavoidable.

Communicate with me (your instructor) or the Office of Student Life if any situation arises that will dramatically impact your attendance in class and at team meetings (e.g. serious illness, injury or personal emergency).

If you are absent from class, it is your responsibility to obtain notes and other materials from colleagues. While you are welcome to book student hours, you should not view them as a substitute for coming to class. If you are absent regularly without a documented extenuating circumstance, requests for student hours meetings may be denied.


Expectations for graded work

Individual assignments
I provide students feedback and/or scores on assignments that require individualized grading before a further assignment of a similar format is due or within 21 days of submission, whichever is shorter. This includes quizzes. I will notify you if I am unable to complete grading within the 21-day timeframe, and will identify a revised return date. If you submit work after the due date, it may not be returned within 21 days, and depending on the justification for late submission, it may not be accepted at all. Your graded coursework will be returned in compliance with FERPA regulations, such as in class, during my student hours, or via the course management system through which only you will have access to your grades.

Course outline




Module Name


Module Learning Outcomes






Baseline Data Literacy


Describe the anatomy of a data set including type (primary process generated or administrative, primary purpose generated, secondary), grouping, and unit of analysis.




Baseline Data Literacy


Distinguish between discrete and continuous variables, and between nominal, ordinal and ratio scale variables.




Baseline Data Literacy


Compute and interpret descriptive statistics relevant to the purpose of the analysis and appropriate for the level of measurement of the variables.




Baseline Data Literacy


Interpret common visual representations of data including bar charts, histograms, and scatter plots.




Baseline Data Literacy


Organize data in a spreadsheet following best practices.




Baseline Data Literacy


Create common visual representations of data including bar charts, histograms, and scatter plots.




Baseline Data Literacy


Demonstrate basic software competencies in spreadsheet software.




Baseline Data Literacy


Define and appropriately use common terms in data analysis including correlation, causation, generalizability, validity, and reliability.




Foundations of Data Analysis (Course LO)


Apply appropriate univariate and bivariate inferential statistics and correctly interpret the results of statistical tests.




Foundations of Data Analysis (Course LO)


Demonstrate basic software competencies in scripting software.




Communication of Results


Curate results generated to identify the most relevant insights and supporting analyses.




Communication of Results


Create clear and compelling visualizations with necessary annotation to achieve stand alone effectiveness.




Communication of Results


Summarize the problem addressed, methods used, results, and implications clearly and concisely in written and oral communication formats intended for non-technical audiences.




Communication of Results


Quantify the implications of alternative solutions or proposed recommendations that follow from analysis.




Communication of Results


Document methods and detailed results of analysis in appendices intended for technical audiences.




Communication of Results


Compose succinct professional emails communicating progress on a project.




Problem Definition


Gather insights from existing reports or others’ analyses to demonstrate and articulate the existence of a business problem or opportunity.




Problem Definition


Define research objectives that are feasible and hypothesis that can be tested using the chosen study methods and data sources.




Problem Definition


Select relevant variables and sources of data needed to analyze an identified business problem or opportunity and propose survey measures when required data do not exist.




Problem Definition


Define key metrics.




Problem Definition


Choose appropriate analysis methods, data, and variables for analyzing the identified problem or opportunity.




Intro to Advanced Topics


Distinguish between observational, quasi-experimental, and observational study designs and select the appropriate design for research objectives and desired use of findings.




Intro to Advanced Topics


Define advanced analysis methods such as regression, forecasting, quasi-experimental and experimental study designs, optimization, machine learning, and text mining, and identify appropriate use cases.




Intro to Advanced Topics


Prepare clear, appropriate, and appealing visual summaries of data in graphs and tables with informative use of color and text.




Intro to Advanced Topics


Prepare data for analysis using sorting, filtering, merging, and additional functions as appropriate.




Intro to Advanced Topics


Design a survey instrument to collect data needed to address a research question, identify potential sources of bias and articulate approach to avoiding bias in the design.




Becoming an Informed Consumer of Data


Suggest relevant alternative explanations for results.




Becoming an Informed Consumer of Data


Correct errors in analysis and interpretation of analysis.




Becoming an Informed Consumer of Data


Describe current debates in research ethics and data privacy and the implications for business research.

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
NotePurpose



This assignment helps you practice the Week 2 question:

How do we clearly describe the data we have?

You will build summary tables only (no charts yet) to describe:

Size (counts, missingness)
Center (mean or median)
Shape (spread: SD or IQR; optional percentiles)
Relationships (categorical ↔︎ categorical; continuous ↔︎ categorical)

You will also reflect briefly on how to use AI responsibly to accelerate—not replace—your thinking.

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
Objectives

Produce clean summary tables (no charts)
Choose statistics that match the measurement scale (NOIR)
Keep denominators straight (N, n_eligible, n_non-missing)
Describe relationships using group summaries and cross-tabs
Communicate results clearly with labels, units, and stated assumptions
Reflect on responsible AI use in data work

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
Resources

Week 2 slides (Size, Center, Shape, Relationships; Percentage Problems)
Week 1 slides (Unit of Analysis / Grain; Dimensions vs Measures; Tidy Data)
Dataset description files on Canvas







TipImportant



This assignment is graded for clear, careful completion.

No charts this week.
Your job is to be explicit and disciplined about what one row represents, what your denominators are, and which summaries are meaningful.

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
1) Choose Your Dataset (Week 1)

Select one of the four Week 1 datasets.
You may keep the same dataset from Homework 1 or switch.
In your submission, state:


Which dataset you used
Any filters or cleaning steps (e.g., removing blanks, focusing on a date range)

(No written response required beyond the brief notes above.)

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
2) Tools (You May Mix and Match)
Complete the tables using Excel, Tableau, posit.cloud, or any combination.

This does not all have to be in one tool.
Choose the tool(s) that best support the table you are trying to build.

(No written response required.)

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
3) Table 1 — Frequency Table (One Categorical Variable)
Create a frequency table for one categorical variable (≥ 3–4 categories recommended).
Your table must include:

Category
Count (n)
Percent of total
Any other information you feel is relevant.

Goal: Describe the distribution. What shows up a lot? What is rare?

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
section: 4) Table 2 — Continuous ↔︎ Categorical (Choose the Right Summary)
text:
4) Table 2 — Continuous ↔︎ Categorical (Choose the Right Summary)
Create a grouped summary table using:

One continuous measure (a numeric variable where arithmetic is meaningful)
One categorical dimension (≥ 3 categories)

Your table must include:

Group name
n_non-missing for the measure
A measure of center and/or measure of spread that matches your choice
Any other information you feel is relevant.

Below the table, write 1–2 sentences explaining why your choices are meaningful.

Tables 2–3 are intentionally flexible: your job is to decide what summary is most meaningful for your variables and explain why.

Hint from Week 2:

Mean/SD are most useful when the variable behaves like interval/ratio data with limited outliers.
Median/IQR are most useful when data are skewed, have outliers, or when “typical” is better captured by the middle.

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
section: 5) Table 3 — Another Continuous ↔︎ Categorical Relationship (Different Angle)
text:
5) Table 3 — Another Continuous ↔︎ Categorical Relationship (Different Angle)
Create a second grouped summary table, changing at least one of the following:

A different continuous measure, or
A different categorical grouping, or
A different summary choice (mean/SD vs median/IQR), or
A different filter or frame (e.g., weekday vs weekend, before vs after a date)

Requirements are the same as Table 2:

Group name
n_non-missing for the measure
A measure of center and/or measure of spread that matches your choice
Any other information you feel is relevant.

Goal: Answer a different question than Table 2.

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
6) Table 4 — Cross-Tab (Categorical ↔︎ Categorical) + Percentages
Create a cross-tab using two categorical variables, each with ≥ 3 categories.
Your table must include:

Cell counts
One percentage type (choose one and label it clearly):

Row % (conditional on row)
Column % (conditional on column)
Table % (overall share)

Row and column totals (margins)

Below the table, write one sentence that states the denominator clearly:

“These percentages are calculated as ________, so each ______ totals to 100%.”

Remember from Week 2:

Similar-sounding percentages can answer different questions. Make the numerator and denominator explicit.

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
(Optional) Continuous ↔︎ Continuous (Correlation Table)
If your dataset includes two continuous variables that might be related, you may include one small correlation table.
This is not required, but it is a strong way to explore whether two measures move together.
If you choose to include it, report:

n_non-missing (pairs)
Correlation r
1 sentence interpretation (direction + strength)

(Still no charts.)

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
7) Findings Summary (Required)
Write 3 key takeaways (about 5–10 sentences total).
Each takeaway must:

Reference a specific table and at least one number (value + category)
Interpret what it implies (not just restate a statistic)

Strong examples:

“Group A has a higher median than Group B (Table 2), suggesting…”
“Under row %, Category X is concentrated in Y (Table 4), meaning…”
“Mean and median disagree (Table 3), which suggests skew/outliers…”

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
section: 8) Responsible Use of AI (Brief Reflection — Required)
text:
8) Responsible Use of AI (Brief Reflection — Required)
AI can help you move faster, but it must not make analytical decisions for you. Use AI only for clarification, rewriting, or troubleshooting.
Write 4–6 sentences responding to:
A. How did you use AI on this assignment? (If not at all, say so.)
B. What did AI help with (specific steps)?
C. What did AI miss, oversimplify, or get wrong?
D. Include one prompt you used and briefly note how it helped and where it fell short.
Remember our goal:

“Can you use AI responsibly to accelerate—not replace—your thinking?”

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
9) Submission
Upload to Canvas:

A PDF or Word document containing:

Tables 1–4 (and the optional correlation table if included)
Your 3 takeaways
Your brief AI reflection

Your supporting files (as applicable):

Excel: .xlsx
Tableau: .twbx
posit.cloud: knitted output (.html or .pdf) and your source file

title: Homework 2: Exploratory Analysis
text:
Alignment to Course Outcomes

Choose the right analysis: You match summaries to measurement scales (NOIR) and keep denominators explicit.
Interpret results in context: Your takeaways connect tables to real questions the data can answer.
Explain limitations, assumptions, and uncertainty: Your justifications and AI reflection surface constraints before conclusions.

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
text:
NotePurpose



This assignment practices the Week 3 goal:

Choose a visualization that matches the analytical frame (the kind of comparison you want the audience to make) and apply perception‑aware design.

You will produce three small visuals (from three different frames) and brief written justifications that explain:

the story you are trying to tell,
why this chart type is the right encoding for that story, and
which design principles you intentionally applied.

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
text:
Objectives

Map a data story to the correct analytical frame and chart form
Apply perceptual design choices from lecture (lines, area, color, clutter)
Communicate with succinct captions, clear scales, and explicit denominators

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
text:
Resources

Week 3 slides (visual perception; analytical frames)
Week 1–2 slides (grain, NOIR, size/center/shape/relationships)
Your Week 1-2 dataset (or any approved course dataset)
Tools: Excel and/or Tableau (you may mix; no code required)







TipImportant




Your grade emphasizes fit‑for‑purpose encodings + clean design.
Include a short brief writeup (3–5 sentences) for each chart.
A Design Checklist is encouraged for each chart (not required).

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
text:
1) Choose Your Dataset (Week 1)

Use one of the four Week 1 datasets (you may keep the same as HW1 & HW2 or change to a different dataset).
Note any filters/cleaning (e.g., date window, excluding blanks).

(No extended writeup—just list what you did.)

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
text:
2) Tools (Excel/Tableau)

Build visuals in Excel and/or Tableau (mixing is fine).
Export images (PNG) at reasonable resolution for pasting into your document.
You may build visuals in posit.cloud if you choose, but that is hard mode.

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
section: 3) Three Visuals — One From Each Module Below
text:
3) Three Visuals — One From Each Module Below
Produce exactly three visuals, selecting one from each module (A, B, C). Avoid repeating the same frame.

A. Comparison (pick one)

Nominal comparison (e.g., side‑by‑side bars) or
Ranking (sorted bars; horizontal recommended)

Design tips: labeled axes, clear units, sorted categories when ranking.


B. Composition or Difference (pick one)

Part‑to‑Whole → Percentages as a bar graph or
Time series of a single metric (line, honest scale) or
Deviation vs a benchmark (bars around zero; clearly label/explain the benchmark)

Design tips: Part to Whole needs to add to 100%, add a zero baseline for deviation, and annotate the benchmark.


C. Distribution or Relationship (pick one)

Frequency distribution (histogram with sensible binning; or boxplot) or
Correlation (scatter; add a simple regression line if appropriate)

Design tips: show units, avoid overplotting marks(alpha if dense), call out outliers

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
section: 4) Brief Writeup Under Each Visual (3–5 sentences)
text:
4) Brief Writeup Under Each Visual (3–5 sentences)
Provide a tight paragraph for each image that includes:

Story: What story are you trying to tell?
Frame & Encoding: Which analytical frame (e.g., part‑to‑whole) and which chart type did you choose—and why is it a fit for this story?
Data Scope: Groupings/filters used; any important denominators or eligibility rules.
Design Principles Applied: Name at least two (e.g., reduced non‑data‑ink; minimal axes; ordered categories; purposeful color; 100% normalization; honest baselines; avoided 3D; judicious regression line).

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
text:
5) Design Checklist (Encouraged)

Chart type matches the analytical frame
Axes and units labeled; baselines honest; scales legible
Appropriate ordering (e.g., sorted bars for ranking)
Color used sparingly (subtle default; vivid only when meaningful)
No 3D or distortions; avoid unnecessary decoration
For composition: 100% normalization, periods sum to 100%
For deviation: benchmark labeled; zero line shown
For correlation: considered trend line; noted limitations

(You are encouraged to follow these checks for each chart; not required to paste the list under every visual.)

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
text:
6) Summary (≤ 200 words)
Write a concise summary that synthesizes what your three visuals reveal. Address whether the story aligns with expectations or surfaces something unexpected.

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
text:
7) Submission
Upload to Canvas:

A Word or PDF document that includes:

Your three visuals (A, B, C) and their brief writeups (3–5 sentences each)
Your Summary (≤ 200 words)

Supporting files as applicable:

Excel: .xlsx
Tableau: .twbx

title: Homework 3: Visualizing Data
text:
8) Grading Focus (What I’m Look For)

Fit‑for‑purpose chart selection given the story & frame
Perceptual clarity: clean baselines, readable scales, sensible color
Sound communication: succinct captions, explicit denominators/assumptions
Overall quality: coherence across the three stories
